title: Hantzsche–Wendt manifold
summary: The Hantzsche–Wendt manifold, also known as the HW manifold or didicosm,[1] is a compact, orientable, flat 3-manifold, first studied by Walter Hantzsche and Hilmar Wendt in 1934.[2] It is the only closed flat 3-manifold with first Betti number zero. Its holonomy group is Z 2 2 {\displaystyle \mathbb {Z} _{2}^{2}} .[3] It has been suggested as a possible shape of the universe because its complicated geometry can obscure the features in the cosmic microwave background that would arise if the universe is a closed flat manifold, such as the 3-torus.[4]
